title: Families Mourn Service Members Killed in Kabul Airport Bombing
sub_head: U.S. military personnel killed in terrorist attack remembered for their commitment and bravery
body:
One called his mother from Kabul on Wednesday, as warnings of an impending attack grew louder, to tell her he was fine.
Another sent videos to his father, showing how he had helped a young boy and girl during Afghans’ desperate rush to the airport seeking passage out of the country. Yet another had shipped out in April, just after his wedding, and stood guarding the airport perimeter this week, his first child’s arrival one month away.
They were among the 13 U.S. service members killed in Thursday’s terrorist attack outside Hamid Karzai International Airport in Afghanistan. The Pentagon hasn’t yet confirmed the names of the victims, but Wall Street Journal reporters spoke with friends and family of some of the deceased.
Here are their stories:
Marine Lance Cpl. David Lee Espinoza, 20 years old, called his mother in Rio Bravo, Texas, on Wednesday. “He said he was fine,” said Elizabeth Holguin. “He said he didn’t want to worry me.”
